dom-blobevent-blobevent.name: BlobEvent
dom-blobevent-blobevent.summary: The BlobEvent() constructor returns a newly created BlobEvent object with an associated Blob.
dom-blobevent-blobevent.title: BlobEvent()

dom-blobevent-data.name: data
dom-blobevent-data.summary: The BlobEvent.data read-only property represents a Blob associated with the event.
dom-blobevent-data.title: BlobEvent.data

dom-blobevent-timecode.name: timecode
dom-blobevent-timecode.summary: The timecode readonlyinline property of the BlobEvent interface a DOMHighResTimeStamp indicating the difference between the timestamp of the first chunk in data, and the timestamp of the first chunk in the first BlobEvent produced by this recorder.
dom-blobevent-timecode.title: BlobEvent.timecode

blobevent-section.name: BlobEvent
blobevent-section.summary: The BlobEvent interface represents events associated with a Blob. These blobs are typically, but not necessarily, associated with media content.
blobevent-section.title: BlobEvent

dom-mediarecorder-mediarecorder.name: MediaRecorder
dom-mediarecorder-mediarecorder.summary: The MediaRecorder() constructor creates a new MediaRecorder object that will record a specified MediaStream.
dom-mediarecorder-mediarecorder.title: MediaRecorder()

dom-mediarecorder-audiobitspersecond.name: audioBitsPerSecond
dom-mediarecorder-audiobitspersecond.summary: The audioBitsPerSecond read-only property of the MediaRecorder interface returns the audio encoding bit rate in use.
dom-mediarecorder-audiobitspersecond.title: MediaRecorder.audioBitsPerSecond

dom-mediarecorder-ondataavailable.name: dataavailable_event
dom-mediarecorder-ondataavailable.summary: The dataavailable event is fired when the MediaRecorder delivers media data to your application for its use. The data is provided in a Blob object that contains the data. This occurs in four situations:
dom-mediarecorder-ondataavailable.title: MediaRecorder: dataavailable event

dom-mediarecorder-onerror.name: error_event
dom-mediarecorder-onerror.summary: The MediaRecorder interface's error event is fired when an error occurs: for example because recording wasn't allowed or was attempted using an unsupported codec.

chrome.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

chrome_android.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

opera.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

opera_android.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

samsunginternet_android.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

webview_android.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

edge_blink.notes: The interface for this event is a plain Event, not MediaRecorderErrorEvent. See bug 1250432.

dom-mediarecorder-onerror.title: MediaRecorder: error event

dom-mediarecorder-istypesupported.name: isTypeSupported
dom-mediarecorder-istypesupported.summary: The MediaRecorder.isTypeSupported() static method returns a Boolean which is true if the MIME type specified is one the user agent should be able to successfully record.
dom-mediarecorder-istypesupported.title: MediaRecorder.isTypeSupported()

dom-mediarecorder-mimetype.name: mimeType
dom-mediarecorder-mimetype.summary: The mimeType read-only property returns the MIME media type that was specified when creating the MediaRecorder object, or, if none was specified, which was chosen by the browser. This is the file format of the file that would result from writing all of the recorded data to disk.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

firefox.notes: Starting with Firefox 71, the behavior of mimeType is more consistent. For example, it now returns the media type even after recording has stopped.

webview_android.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

dom-mediarecorder-mimetype.title: MediaRecorder.mimeType

dom-mediarecorder-pause.name: pause
dom-mediarecorder-pause.summary: The Media.pause() method (part of the MediaRecorder API) is used to pause recording of media streams.
dom-mediarecorder-pause.title: MediaRecorder.pause()

dom-mediarecorder-onpause.name: pause_event
dom-mediarecorder-onpause.summary: The pause event is thrown as a result of the MediaRecorder.pause() method being invoked.
dom-mediarecorder-onpause.title: MediaRecorder: pause event

dom-mediarecorder-requestdata.name: requestData
dom-mediarecorder-requestdata.summary: The MediaRecorder.requestData() method (part of the MediaRecorder API) is used to raise a dataavailable event containing a Blob object of the captured media as it was when the method was called. This can then be grabbed and manipulated as you wish.
dom-mediarecorder-requestdata.title: MediaRecorder.requestData()

dom-mediarecorder-resume.name: resume
dom-mediarecorder-resume.summary: The MediaRecorder.resume() method (part of the MediaRecorder API) is used to resume media recording when it has been previously paused.
dom-mediarecorder-resume.title: MediaRecorder.resume()

dom-mediarecorder-onresume.name: resume_event
dom-mediarecorder-onresume.summary: The resume event is thrown when MediaRecorder.resume() is called.
dom-mediarecorder-onresume.title: MediaRecorder: resume event

dom-mediarecorder-start.name: start
dom-mediarecorder-start.summary: The MediaRecorder method start(), which is part of the MediaStream Recording API, begins recording media into one or more Blob objects.
dom-mediarecorder-start.title: MediaRecorder.start()

dom-mediarecorder-onstart.name: start_event
dom-mediarecorder-onstart.summary: The start event is fired when MediaRecorder.start() is called. At this point, the data starts being gathered into a Blob.
dom-mediarecorder-onstart.title: MediaRecorder: start event

dom-mediarecorder-state.name: state
dom-mediarecorder-state.summary: The MediaRecorder.state read-only property returns the current state of the current MediaRecorder object.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

webview_android.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

dom-mediarecorder-state.title: MediaRecorder.state

dom-mediarecorder-stop.name: stop
dom-mediarecorder-stop.summary: The MediaRecorder.stop() method (part of the MediaRecorder API) is used to stop media capture.
dom-mediarecorder-stop.title: MediaRecorder.stop()

dom-mediarecorder-onstop.name: stop_event
dom-mediarecorder-onstop.summary: The stop event is fired when MediaRecorder.stop() is called, or when the media stream being captured ends. In each case, the stop event is preceded by a dataavailable event, making the Blob captured up to that point available for you to use in your application.
dom-mediarecorder-onstop.title: MediaRecorder: stop event

dom-mediarecorder-stream.name: stream
dom-mediarecorder-stream.summary: The MediaRecorder.stream read-only property returns the stream that was passed into the MediaRecorder() constructor when the MediaRecorder was created.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 49, only video is supported, not audio.

dom-mediarecorder-stream.title: MediaRecorder.stream

dom-mediarecorder-videobitspersecond.name: videoBitsPerSecond
dom-mediarecorder-videobitspersecond.summary: The videoBitsPerSecond read-only property of the MediaRecorder interface returns the video encoding bit rate in use.
dom-mediarecorder-videobitspersecond.title: MediaRecorder.videoBitsPerSecond

mediarecorder-api.name: MediaRecorder
mediarecorder-api.summary: The MediaRecorder interface of the MediaStream Recording API provides functionality to easily record media. It is created using the MediaRecorder() constructor.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 58, using MediaStream.addTrack() on a stream obtained using getUserMedia(), then attempting to record the resulting stream would result in only recording the original stream without the added tracks (severe bug).

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 58, using MediaStream.addTrack() on a stream obtained using getUserMedia(), then attempting to record the resulting stream would result in only recording the original stream without the added tracks (severe bug).

mediarecorder-api.title: MediaRecorder

dom-mediarecordererrorevent-mediarecorde.name: MediaRecorderErrorEvent
dom-mediarecordererrorevent-mediarecorde.summary: The MediaRecorderErrorEvent() constructor creates a new MediaRecorderErrorEvent object that represents an error that occurred during the recording of media by the MediaStream Recording API.
dom-mediarecordererrorevent-mediarecorde.title: MediaRecorderErrorEvent()

dom-mediarecordererrorevent-error.name: error
dom-mediarecordererrorevent-error.summary: The read-only error property in the MediaRecorderErrorEvent interface is a DOMException object providing details about the exception that was thrown by a MediaRecorder instance.
dom-mediarecordererrorevent-error.title: MediaRecorderErrorEvent.error

errorevent-section.name: MediaRecorderErrorEvent
errorevent-section.summary: The MediaRecorderErrorEvent interface represents errors returned by the MediaStream Recording API. It is an Event object that encapsulates a reference to a DOMException describing the error that occurred.
errorevent-section.title: MediaRecorderErrorEvent
